stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream prototyping and coding a new snowman enemy for the ice-themed course, tweaking its model, collision, animation and behaviour while discussing upcoming optimisation work (Sauraen’s trace) and a toggleable anti-aliasing option.

development_findings.summary: A new two-segment snowman enemy is being added; the head detaches and rolls toward Mario. Kaze debated having two faces vs. a single hidden face and settled on one visible face with alpha to simplify animation.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking of making snowmen like this… they're going to roll their head at you.

development_findings.summary: Implemented rolling-head mechanics: scaling, collision radius, rotation maths, attack distance and ground movement were debugged live; slope physics and shatter effect are still TODO.
Plan to include a pushable snowman in the first room that crashes through a window to reveal a hidden star.
development_findings.quote: We need a snowman here you push and it falls into this window and there's a star behind it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is integrating Sauraen’s trace tool; expects it to expose ‘stupid things’ and give ‘huge boosts’ to performance, making further optimisation easier.
development_findings.quote: Once Sauraen's trace is in, it's going to make optimisation so much easier.

development_findings.summary: An N64 hardware test build of RTY already runs ‘near perfect’ without any optimisation, increasing confidence in final performance.
development_findings.quote: It ran near perfect without even optimising anything.

development_findings.summary: Created a stripped-down test overworld so any level can be entered quickly during development; the official overworld is temporarily disabled.
A toggleable anti-aliasing option is being programmed offline; this will allow players to switch AA on or off at runtime.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has several days off from his day job and is using the time to tackle long-postponed features such as the NA/AA options and optimisation framework.
He and Zeina are expecting their first child in roughly two weeks, adding personal urgency and excitement to the project timeline.
context_findings.quote: Can you guys believe it's just two weeks until my child is born?

context_findings.summary: After Return to Yoshi’s Island, Kaze intends to move on to developing an original game rather than another SM64 hack.
context_findings.quote: When you finish this, I'm probably going to make my own game at that point.

context_findings.summary: Zeina now works from a separate home office after their move, explaining her reduced on-stream presence.

biobak.summary: Provided live artistic feedback on the snowman (second face concerns) and level aesthetics (e.g., suggesting an ‘ice carpet’ and joking about a ‘piss carpet’).

zeina.summary: Appeared in chat, offered lighthearted banter; Kaze noted she handles his hair-shaving (‘balding’) and has her own office setup now.

key_stories.title: Building the Rolling-Head Snowman
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a memorable enemy for the ice castle. Together with chat (notably Biobak), he brainstormed a two-segment snowman whose head rolls at Mario. He debated visual quirks (extra face, alpha tricks), coded the behaviour live, fixed scaling bugs and tuned attack speed.
key_stories.challenge: Create a new enemy that fits the theme and offers fresh gameplay.
key_stories.process: Sketch design → chat feedback → model tweaks → collision maths → live code/debug of rolling mechanics.
key_stories.outcome: Functional prototype exists; remaining tasks are slope physics and shatter effect.
key_stories.key_quote: I kind of want him to look at Mario here… we got something now.

key_stories.title: Surprisingly Smooth N64 Hardware Test
key_stories.summary: A recent on-hardware test of RTY shocked Kaze by running almost flawlessly despite no manual optimisation, boosting morale and informing future performance goals.
key_stories.challenge: Verify whether the expanding hack still runs acceptably on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Compiled unoptimised build → ran on console → monitored framerate.
key_stories.outcome: Near-perfect performance; optimisation pass now viewed as icing on the cake.
key_stories.key_quote: It ran near perfect without even optimising anything.

key_stories.title: Preparing for Deep Optimisation with Sauraen’s Trace
key_stories.summary: Kaze is importing Sauraen’s trace tool to identify bottlenecks. He expects it to streamline profiling and reveal ‘huge’ speed gains once integrated.
key_stories.challenge: Manual profiling has become cumbersome as the project scales.
key_stories.process: Coordinate with Sauraen, begin integration steps, discuss expected benefits on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Tool not yet active but treated as priority task during his time off.
key_stories.key_quote: Once Sauraen's trace is in, we'll probably find so many stupid things going on that will give us huge boosts.

open_questions.context: Kaze says the profiler will ‘make optimisation so much easier’ but gives no technical details.
questions: What specific metrics will Sauraen’s trace expose that current tools miss?
Can he describe an example of an expected ‘huge boost’ it might uncover?
How did the collaboration with Sauraen come about?

open_questions.context: He is coding an ‘enable NA/AA option’ offline and mentions a runtime toggle.
questions: What technical hurdles exist when adding real-time AA on N64 hardware?
Will players be able to choose different AA strengths or just on/off?
Does AA impact performance on real hardware, and how will he balance that?

open_questions.context: He references a future ‘room system’ to hide geometry and improve FPS but hasn’t implemented it yet.
questions: How will the room system be structured and triggered?
What lessons from the SM64 engine inform his approach?
Any new tooling required to author room boundaries efficiently?

open_questions.context: Long discussion about wanting a ‘minty’ or rhyming name but no decision.
questions: What emotions or imagery does he want players to feel entering this course?
How does he normally decide on course names, and what role do team members play?
Could Biobak or the community formally pitch names, and how will Kaze pick one?

open_questions.context: He plans a snowman you push through a window to reveal a star but hasn’t coded it.
questions: What collision and camera challenges are expected for this set-piece?
Will breakable windows become a reusable mechanic elsewhere?
How does he balance ‘wow factor’ vs. difficulty for first-time players?

open_questions.context: Kaze casually says he’ll make his own game afterwards.
questions: Does he envision staying on N64 hardware, moving to PC or another platform?
What genres or mechanics excite him beyond platformers?
Would current team members (Biobak, Badub, Zeina) carry over to that project?
